Comment: This is my first annotation project. I wish to thank tennesseehiker, founder of Knights of Honor Chess Club, high rated players for giving me the opportunity to play with them and Fatcat2 for the invite and for reading the preprint of this annotation.

Viktor Moskalenko advocates this move. The Bishop takes the important diagonal b1-h7, supports the e4 and f4 pawns and pieces for future attack
Maybe too slow. It prevents Nc3-b5, but at this point White plan is playing on king side.

Provocation. If 11. ... h6 then the Knight simply retreats to f3 or h3 and the g6 square will become weaker
Maybe unnecessary, but this prevents nasty tactics with Black Bishop at d4. Wait and see...

Just developing a piece and preparing to connect the Rooks.
Just developing a piece and preparing to connect the Rooks.
An error. This creates a strong outpost at d5 for the c3-Knight.
A blunder. This pawn was defended twice. Piece for a pawn and it frees the b1-h7 diagonal.

With this exchange sacrifice White has a powerful king side attack. White must remove the f6-Knight and that can be done with tempo because at this point there is the threat Ne6, forking Queen and Rook.

13. ... e5 was an error. Now the Knight will leave the important f6-square, the defense of h7, h5 and g4.

This move introduces a "mate" in 6 sequence. I announced that (sorry Fatcat2) and triggered the moves until I realized that the d5 Knight should be eliminated first. It would be a terrible a blunder.
Alternative variation: 19. Bxh7+ [My intuition was said that there were some tactics here and i would played that in a friendly OTB blitz game.] Kh8 20. cxd5
Alternative variation: 19. Qxd5+ Kh8 20. Nf7+ Rxf7 21. Qxf7 [This gives White the Exchange back and will be up a Bishop for a passed pawn. I don't like the position.]

Shocking. This move escaped my analysis. White must give up his Knight.
